connective tissue.
At the posterior end of the stomach, which is rounded 
off, are the Malpighian tubules.
Fig. 2 represents the alimentary canal of the imago 
of <u>Pontia <\u>. The pharynx passes into a narrow, but 
long, oesophagus leading into a crop or food receptacle.
This crop is entirely absent in the larval, but is develop-
ed in the pupal stage. It’s delicate cuticular walls 
are internally thrown into numerous wrinkles;
near the neck is a region armed with processes,
scale-like in shape, each process being armed with 
from six to eight teeth. The neck of the crop has an 
investment of transverse, annular, muscular 
fibres.
The stomach is much smaller than in the larva,
but its lining is also thrown into glandular follicles.
The posterior end of the stomach leads into a long,
and peculiarly coiled, small intestine. The intestine 
passes into a wide terminal division, the rectum,
from the front end of which there is a curved
